name: Kepler-322
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-322 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-322 is a star with 0.785 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.89 times its radius. It is located 1321.45 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-322 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-322 b

Kepler-322 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 1.65 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-322.

The mass of Kepler-322 b is 0.98 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-322 b is 1.01 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-322 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-322 c

Kepler-322 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.34 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-322.

The mass of Kepler-322 c is 3.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-322 c is 1.67 that of Earth. At 3.29 Earth masses, Kepler-322 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-322, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
